title: Present Simple
description: We use the present simple to talk about habits, routines, and facts.

structure.pattern: subject + base verb (+ s/es for he/she/it)

examples.es: A ellos no les gusta el café.

examples.en: I wake up at 7 AM every morning.
examples.es: Me despierto a las 7 AM todas las mañanas.

examples.en: The sun rises in the east.
examples.es: El sol sale por el este.
Ella juega tenis los fines de semana.

tips: Add 's' or 'es' to the verb for he/she/it (third person singular)
Use 'do not' (don't) for I/you/we/they
Use 'does not' (doesn't) for he/she/it
Time expressions like 'always', 'usually', 'often' are common with present simple

title: Past Simple
description: We use the past simple to talk about completed actions in the past.

examples.es: Ella jugó tenis la semana pasada.

examples.en: She didn't come to the party.
examples.es: Ella no vino a la fiesta.

examples.en: We met at the café yesterday.
examples.es: Nos conocimos en el café ayer.

tips: Regular verbs add -ed (work → worked)
Irregular verbs change form (go → went, see → saw)
Use 'did not' (didn't) for all subjects in negative
Time expressions like 'yesterday', 'last week', 'ago' indicate past simple

title: Present Continuous
description: We use the present continuous to talk about actions happening now or temporary situations.

examples.en: I'm learning to play the guitar.
examples.es: Estoy aprendiendo a tocar la guitarra.

examples.en: She's working in London this month.
examples.es: Ella está trabajando en Londres este mes.

tips: Use 'am' for I, 'is' for he/she/it, 'are' for you/we/they
Add -ing to the base verb
Use for actions happening now or around now
Not used with stative verbs (like, know, understand)

title: Comparatives
description: We use comparatives to compare two things or people.

examples.en: This car is faster than that one.
examples.es: Este auto es más rápido que ese.

examples.en: She is taller than her sister.
examples.es: Ella es más alta que su hermana.

examples.en: This movie is more interesting than that one.
examples.es: Esta película es más interesante que esa.
El inglés es más fácil que el chino.

examples.en: This restaurant is more expensive than the other one.
examples.es: Este restaurante es más caro que el otro.

tips: One-syllable adjectives: add -er (fast → faster)
Two-syllable adjectives ending in -y: change y to i and add -er (happy → happier)
Long adjectives: use 'more' + adjective
Irregular: good → better, bad → worse, far → farther/further

title: Future with Will
description: We use 'will' to talk about future predictions, promises, and spontaneous decisions.

examples.en: Will you come to the party?
We will never forget this moment.

tips: Will is the same for all subjects
Use 'won't' for the negative form
Common for predictions, promises, and quick decisions
Often used with 'probably', 'maybe', 'I think'

title: Present Perfect
description: We use the present perfect to talk about past actions with a connection to the present.

examples.en: I have lived here for five years.
examples.es: He vivido aquí por cinco años.
examples.note: Action started in past, continues to present

examples.en: Have you ever been to Japan?

tips: Use 'have' for I/you/we/they, 'has' for he/she/it
Use past participle: regular (worked) or irregular (gone, seen)
Common with 'ever', 'never', 'already', 'yet', 'just', 'for', 'since'
Connects past action to present moment
